groups.Coastal Phytoplankton: Microscopic algae (diatoms, dinoflagellates, etc.) forming the base of the coastal food web.  High resolution needed due to seasonal variability and influence of nutrient runoff.
groups.Pelagic Phytoplankton: Microscopic algae (diatoms, coccolithophores, etc.) forming the base of the open ocean food web. High resolution needed due to seasonal variability and influence of currents.
groups.Coastal Zooplankton: Small animals (copepods, krill, etc.) grazing on phytoplankton in coastal waters.  Includes larval stages of many fish and invertebrates. High resolution needed due to seasonal variability and influence of currents.
groups.Pelagic Zooplankton: Small animals (copepods, krill, jellyfish, etc.) grazing on phytoplankton in open ocean waters.  Includes larval stages of many fish and invertebrates. High resolution needed due to seasonal variability and influence of currents.
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Shallow): A diverse group of bottom-dwelling invertebrates (e.g., crustaceans, mollusks, polychaetes) found in shallow coastal areas, including seagrass beds and rocky reefs.  Includes both deposit feeders and predators. High resolution needed for key species in specific habitats (e.g., seagrass beds, kelp forests).
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Deep): A diverse group of bottom-dwelling invertebrates found in deeper waters of the continental slope and abyssal plain. Includes deposit feeders, filter feeders, and predators.  Higher resolution needed for key species in specific habitats (e.g., seamounts, cold seeps).
groups.Planktivores (Coastal): Small fish that feed primarily on zooplankton in coastal waters.  Important link between lower and higher trophic levels. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Planktivores (Pelagic): Small fish that feed primarily on zooplankton in open ocean waters.  Important link between lower and higher trophic levels. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Small Benthic Fish (Coastal): Small fish feeding on benthic invertebrates in shallow coastal areas.  Includes species associated with seagrass beds and rocky reefs. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Small Benthic Fish (Slope/Deep): Small fish feeding on benthic invertebrates in deeper waters of the continental slope and abyssal plain. High resolution needed for key species in specific habitats (e.g., seamounts).
groups.Mid-sized Demersal Fish (Coastal): Medium-sized bottom-dwelling fish feeding on a mix of invertebrates and smaller fish in coastal waters. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Mid-sized Demersal Fish (Slope/Deep): Medium-sized bottom-dwelling fish feeding on a mix of invertebrates and smaller fish in deeper waters. High resolution needed for key species in specific habitats (e.g., seamounts).
groups.Large Pelagic Piscivores: Large predatory fish (e.g., tuna, billfish) feeding on smaller fish in open ocean waters. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Large Demersal Piscivores (Coastal): Large predatory fish feeding on other fish in coastal waters. High resolution needed for commercially important species.
groups.Large Demersal Piscivores (Slope/Deep): Large predatory fish feeding on other fish in deeper waters. High resolution needed for key species in specific habitats (e.g., seamounts).
groups.Seabirds (Nearshore): Small to medium-sized seabirds (e.g., gulls, terns, penguins) feeding near the coast. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Seabirds (Pelagic): Large pelagic seabirds (e.g., albatrosses, petrels) feeding on fish and squid in open ocean waters. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Pinnipeds (Fish-eating): Seals and sea lions that primarily feed on fish. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Pinnipeds (Invertebrate-eating): Seals that primarily feed on krill and other invertebrates. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Baleen Whales: Large filter-feeding whales that feed on zooplankton. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Toothed Whales/Dolphins: Smaller toothed whales and dolphins that feed on fish and squid. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Orcas: Apex predators feeding on other marine mammals, fish, and sharks. High resolution needed.
groups.Sharks (Coastal): Sharks inhabiting coastal waters, including reef sharks and other species. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Sharks (Pelagic): Sharks inhabiting open ocean waters. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Sharks (Demersal): Bottom-dwelling sharks. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Cephalopods: Squid and octopus, important predators in various habitats. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Sea Turtles: Herbivorous and omnivorous sea turtles. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Seagrass: Seagrass beds providing habitat and food for many species. High resolution needed.
groups.Kelp Forests: Kelp forests providing habitat and food for many species. High resolution needed.
groups.Rocky Reefs: Rocky reefs providing habitat for many species. High resolution needed.
groups.Sandy/Muddy Sediments: Sandy and muddy sediments supporting infaunal communities. High resolution needed for key species.
groups.Detritus: Organic matter from dead organisms and waste products, supporting decomposers and detritivores.
groups.Sedimentary Bacteria: Bacteria in sediments playing a crucial role in nutrient cycling.  Consider modelling as a single group unless high-resolution data is available to differentiate functional types.

groups.Coastal Pelagic Fish: Small to medium-sized fish inhabiting the pelagic zone of coastal waters, including species like anchovies, pilchards, and smaller schooling fish.  They are primarily planktivores and serve as a crucial link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.  This group may need higher resolution to account for species-specific differences in diet and distribution.
groups.Bass Strait Pelagic Fish: Pelagic fish species found predominantly in the Bass Strait, including species that may undertake migrations.  This group could include commercially important species like jack mackerel and other schooling fish.  Higher resolution may be needed to differentiate between migratory and resident species and their respective diets.
groups.Tasman Sea Pelagic Fish: Pelagic fish species inhabiting the open waters of the Tasman Sea, including larger, more migratory species like tuna and billfish. This group may also include some smaller schooling fish. Higher resolution is needed to account for the diversity of species and their migratory patterns.
groups.Shelf Demersal Fish (Small Benthivores): Small demersal fish inhabiting the continental shelf, primarily feeding on benthic invertebrates.  This group represents a key link between benthic and pelagic ecosystems.  Higher resolution may be needed to account for species-specific differences in diet and habitat preference.
groups.Shelf Demersal Fish (Omnivores): Medium-sized demersal fish on the continental shelf with a mixed diet of invertebrates and smaller fish.  They play a significant role in benthic food webs. Higher resolution may be needed to differentiate between species with varying degrees of piscivory.
groups.Shelf Demersal Fish (Piscivores): Medium to large demersal fish on the continental shelf that primarily feed on other fish.  They are important predators regulating prey fish populations. Higher resolution is needed to differentiate between species with varying size and prey preferences.
groups.Slope/Deep Demersal Fish (Benthivores): Small to medium-sized demersal fish inhabiting the continental slope and deeper waters, feeding primarily on benthic invertebrates.  This group may include species adapted to deeper, colder environments. Higher resolution may be needed to account for species-specific adaptations to depth and pressure.
groups.Slope/Deep Demersal Fish (Omnivores): Medium-sized demersal fish on the continental slope and deeper waters with a mixed diet of invertebrates and smaller fish. Higher resolution may be needed to differentiate between species with varying degrees of piscivory and habitat preferences.
groups.Slope/Deep Demersal Fish (Piscivores): Medium to large demersal fish on the continental slope and deeper waters that primarily feed on other fish.  They are important predators in deeper ecosystems. Higher resolution is needed to differentiate between species with varying size and prey preferences.
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Filter Feeders): Bottom-dwelling invertebrates that filter feed, including bivalves, sponges, and crinoids.  They play a crucial role in nutrient cycling and water quality. Higher resolution may be needed to differentiate between species with varying filter-feeding strategies and habitat preferences.
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Deposit Feeders): Bottom-dwelling invertebrates that feed on organic matter in sediments, including sea cucumbers and some polychaetes.  They are important in sediment processing and nutrient cycling.
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Grazers): Bottom-dwelling invertebrates that graze on algae and detritus, including sea urchins and some gastropods.  They influence benthic community structure and algal growth.
groups.Benthic Invertebrates (Carnivores): Predatory benthic invertebrates, including crabs, lobsters, and some starfish.  They are important predators in benthic food webs.
groups.Zooplankton (Large Carnivores): Larger predatory zooplankton, including fish larvae and arrow worms.  They feed on smaller zooplankton and serve as prey for larger animals. Higher resolution may be needed to differentiate between species and their prey preferences.
groups.Zooplankton (Herbivores): Smaller zooplankton that feed on phytoplankton, including copepods and some cladocerans.  They are a crucial link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.
groups.Phytoplankton (Diatoms): Diatoms are a dominant group of phytoplankton in many marine environments, forming the base of the food web.  Higher resolution may be needed to account for species-specific differences in nutrient requirements and growth rates.
groups.Phytoplankton (Dinoflagellates): Dinoflagellates are another important group of phytoplankton, some of which are mixotrophic (capable of both photosynthesis and heterotrophy). Higher resolution may be needed to account for species-specific differences in nutrient requirements and growth rates.
groups.Seabirds (Nearshore): Small to medium-sized seabirds that forage near the coast, including gulls, terns, and possibly penguins.  They link marine and terrestrial ecosystems.
groups.Seabirds (Pelagic): Large pelagic seabirds that forage exclusively at sea, including albatrosses and petrels.  They feed on fish, squid, and other marine organisms.
groups.Pinnipeds (Fish-Eaters): Marine mammals (seals, sea lions) that primarily prey on fish in coastal and pelagic ecosystems.
groups.Pinnipeds (Invertebrate-Eaters): Marine mammals that primarily feed on krill and other invertebrates.
groups.Cetaceans (Baleen Whales): Large filter-feeding whales that regulate zooplankton populations and contribute to nutrient cycling.
groups.Cetaceans (Toothed Whales): Toothed whales and dolphins that primarily feed on fish and squid.
groups.Cetaceans (Sperm Whales): Deep-diving sperm whales that primarily feed on deep-water squid and fish.
groups.Cetaceans (Orcas): Apex predators that prey on other top predators, including marine mammals, sharks, and large fish.
groups.Sharks (Pelagic): Open-ocean sharks that help regulate populations of fishes and squids.
groups.Sharks (Demersal): Bottom-dwelling sharks that control populations of fishes and invertebrates on and near the seafloor.
groups.Sharks (Reef): Top predators in reef ecosystems, controlling fish populations and maintaining reef health.
groups.Seagrass: Seagrass beds provide important habitat and nursery areas for many species. Higher resolution may be needed to account for different seagrass species and their distribution.
groups.Kelp Forests: Kelp forests provide habitat and food for a diverse range of species, particularly along the continental shelf. Higher resolution may be needed to account for different kelp species and their distribution.
groups.Rocky Reefs: Rocky reefs provide habitat for a diverse range of species. Higher resolution may be needed to account for different reef types and their associated communities.
groups.Sandy/Muddy Sediments: Sandy and muddy sediments support benthic communities. Higher resolution may be needed to account for different sediment types and their associated communities.
groups.Detritus: Organic matter from dead organisms and waste products, forming a crucial food source for many benthic organisms.
groups.Fisheries Discards: Material discarded from fishing activities, which can have significant impacts on the ecosystem.

groups.Skuas and Giant Petrels: Large predatory seabirds that feed both at sea and on land. This group is a top predator.
groups.Pinnipeds (Fish-eating): Seals and sea lions that primarily prey on fish. This group is a top predator.
groups.Pinnipeds (Invertebrate-eating): Seals that primarily feed on krill and other invertebrates. This group is a top predator.
groups.Baleen Whales: Large filter-feeding whales that regulate zooplankton populations. This group is a top predator.
groups.Orcas: Apex predators that prey on other top predators. This group is a top predator.
groups.Sperm Whales: Deep-diving whales that primarily feed on deep-water squid and fish. This group is a top predator.
groups.Small Toothed Whales and Dolphins: Smaller cetaceans that primarily feed on fish and squid. This group is a top predator.
groups.Detritus: Organic matter from dead organisms and waste products, serving as a food source for many detritivores.
groups.Sedimentary Bacteria: Microbial community in sediments, crucial for nutrient cycling.  This group is often implicitly included in other groups but could be explicitly modeled in a higher-resolution model.
groups.Pelagic Bacteria: Microbial community in the water column, crucial for nutrient cycling.  This group is often implicitly included in other groups but could be explicitly modeled in a higher-resolution model.

groups.Description: Includes discards, detritus, and refractory organic matter.
Decomposing organic matter that provides food and habitat for many organisms.
Includes the vegetation and associated fauna of mangrove forests and salt marshes.

groups.Phytoplankton: Primary producers that form the base of the marine food web, converting sunlight into energy through photosynthesis, and are consumed by zooplankton and other herbivores
groups.Seagrass: Marine flowering plants that form important coastal habitats and nursery areas, providing shelter and food for many species, including fish, crustaceans, and birds
groups.Mangroves: Salt-tolerant trees forming critical coastal nursery habitats and protecting shorelines, providing a complex network of roots that support a diverse array of marine life
groups.Macroalgae: Seaweeds of various sizes that provide habitat and food for many species, including both canopy and understory forms, and play a crucial role in primary production and nutrient cycling

groups.Mesozooplankton: Medium-sized zooplankton that feed on smaller plankton and serve as food for larger animals, playing a crucial role in energy transfer between trophic levels
groups.Microzooplankton: Tiny zooplankton that graze on phytoplankton and bacteria, forming a crucial link in the microbial food web and influencing the cycling of nutrients
groups.Benthic Filter Feeders: Bottom-dwelling organisms that filter water for food, important in nutrient cycling and regulating water quality in various depths, including bivalves, crinoids, and sponges

groups.Reef Herbivores: Herbivorous fish and sea turtles that control algal growth and maintain reef health.
groups.Pelagic Herbivores: Includes fish such as flying fish and mesopelagic fish that feed on plankton, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of plankton populations.
groups.Benthic Herbivores: Includes sea urchins, sea cucumbers, and benthic grazers, controlling algal growth and affecting benthic community structure.
groups.Reef Corals: Reef-building colonial animals that create complex habitat structure through calcium carbonate deposition, providing shelter and habitat for a variety of organisms.
groups.Soft Corals and Sea Anemones: Colonial animals that contribute to reef habitat complexity without building calcium carbonate structures, providing shelter and habitat for a variety of organisms.
groups.Pelagic Bacteria and Phytoplankton: Includes diatoms, dinoflagellates, nanoplankton, picoplankton, and pelagic bacteria, forming the base of the marine food web and contributing to nutrient cycling.
groups.Benthic Bacteria and Microalgae: Includes sedimentary bacteria, meiobenthos, benthic filter feeders, and microalgae, forming the base of the benthic food web and contributing to nutrient cycling.
groups.Zooplankton: Includes mesozooplankton, microzooplankton, and large carnivorous zooplankton, serving as food for larger animals and contributing to energy transfer.
groups.Seagrass, Mangroves, and Salt Marsh Plan: Marine and coastal vegetation that form important habitats and nursery areas, contributing to nutrient cycling and shoreline protection.
groups.Mesopelagic Benthivores: Small to mid-sized fish that feed on benthic organisms and live in the mesopelagic zone, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of benthic populations.
groups.Deep-sea Benthivores: Small to mid-sized fish that feed on benthic organisms and live on the shelf or seamounts, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of benthic populations.
groups.Deep-sea Demersal Fish: Medium to large demersal fish that live in slope or seamount waters, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of demersal populations.
groups.Pelagic Sharks: Open-ocean predators that help regulate populations of fishes and squids, occupying high trophic levels.
groups.Discards and Detritus: Carrion, freshly discarded material from fisheries activities, and detritus, serving as food for scavengers and decomposers, contributing to nutrient cycling.

groups.Pelagic Fish-eating Predators: Large predatory fish such as tunas and billfishes that occupy high trophic levels in the open ocean, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of prey populations.
groups.Reef Fish-eating Predators: Medium to large predatory fish that inhabit coral reefs, controlling prey fish populations and maintaining reef health.
groups.Demersal Fish-eating Predators: Bottom-dwelling predatory fish, including dogfishes, that control populations of fishes and invertebrates on and near the seafloor.
groups.Reef Invertebrate Predators: Includes reef sharks, skates, rays, and large predatory invertebrates such as octopus and sea anemones, controlling populations of reef-dwelling organisms.
groups.Pelagic Invertebrate Predators: Includes cephalopods and jellyfish, important predators in open ocean ecosystems, particularly on zooplankton.
groups.Benthic Invertebrate Predators: Includes starfish, sea urchins, and benthic carnivorous zooplankton, controlling populations of benthic invertebrates.
